Package com.idevicesinc.sweetblue.utils

Class Event

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.idevicesinc.sweetblue.utils.Event
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AddServiceListener.ServiceAddEvent, AdvertisingListener.AdvertisingEvent, AssertListener.AssertEvent, BleNodeConfig.HistoricalDataLogFilter.HistoricalDataLogEvent, BluetoothEnabler.BluetoothEnablerFilter.BluetoothEnablerEvent, BondFilter.CharacteristicEvent, BondFilter.ConnectionBugEvent, BondListener.BondEvent, BondRetryFilter.RetryEvent, DescriptorFilter.DescriptorEvent, DeviceConnectListener.ConnectEvent, DiscoveryListener.DiscoveryEvent, ExchangeListener.ExchangeEvent, HistoricalDataLoadListener.HistoricalDataLoadEvent, HistoricalDataQueryListener.HistoricalDataQueryEvent, MtuTestCallback.MtuTestEvent, NotificationListener.NotificationEvent, ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent, ReconnectFilter.ConnectFailEvent, ReconnectFilter.ConnectionLostEvent, ResetListener.ResetEvent, ScanFilter.ScanEvent, ServerConnectListener.ConnectEvent, State.ChangeEvent, TaskTimeoutRequestFilter.TaskTimeoutRequestEvent, UhOhListener.UhOhEvent
    public abstract class Event
extends java.lang.Object
    Abstract base class for all events in SweetBlue, e.g. State.ChangeEvent.

    • Method Detail

      • isFor

        public boolean isFor​(java.lang.Object value)
        More reader-friendly of isForAll(Object...) or isForAny(Object...) in the event you only have one parameter to match.

      • isForAny

        public boolean isForAny​(java.lang.Object... values)
        Convenience query method to check if this event "is for"/relevant-to any of the supplied values. For example for ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent you could write e.isForAny("DE:CA::FF:CO::FF::EE", "DE:AD:BE:EF:BA:BE") to quickly check if the event is associated with either of the two devices. This method would then just do a comparison with the input strings against ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.macAddress().

      • isForAll

        public boolean isForAll​(java.lang.Object... values)
        Convenience query method to check if this event "is for"/relevant-to all of the supplied values. For example for ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent you could write e.isForAll("DE:CA::FF:CO::FF::EE", MY_UUID) to quickly check if the event is associated with both the given mac address and the given UUID (e.g. for a characteristic). This method would then just do a comparison with the input values against ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.macAddress(), ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.charUuid() ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.descUuid(), and ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.serviceUuid().
